bestBHT.bht: Jesus, deeply moved once again, approached the tomb of Lazarus, and found a cave with a stone laid against it. The use of a cave for burial was common during that time, and this particular tomb, belonging to a wealthy family, had a stone placed over the entrance for protection. Jesus' groaning within Himself revealed a mixture of sorrow and righteous indignation as He prepared to confront death and demonstrate His power in raising Lazarus. This detail about the stone also highlighted Mary's objection to its removal, as it would expose the decaying body of her brother.

Henry Alford: The caves were generally horizontal, natural or artificial,—with recesses in the sides, where the bodies were laid.
Graves were of both kinds: we have the vertically sunk mentioned Luke xi. 44. Compare Isa. xxii. 16; 2 Chron. xvi. 14; 2 Kings xxiii. 16.
Probably, from this circumstance, as from ‘the Jews’ coming to condole,—and the costly ointment (ch. xii. 3),—the family was wealthy.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Jesus again groaning in himself—that is, as at :-, checked or repressed His rising feelings, in the former instance, of sorrow, here of righteous indignation at their unreasonable unbelief...
...struggling emotion was deeper, now that His eye was about to rest on the spot where lay, in the still horrors of death, His 'friend'.

a cave—the cavity, natural or artificial, of a rock. This, with the number of condoling visitors from Jerusalem, and the costly ointment with which Mary afterwards anointed Jesus at Bethany, all go to show that the family was in good circumstances.
Albert Barnes: It was a cave - This was a common mode of burial. See the notes at Matthew 8:28.
A stone lay upon it - Over the mouth of the cave. See Matthew 27:60.
Marvin Vincent: The stone was placed over the entrance mainly to guard against wild beasts, and could easily be removed.

An apparently superfluous detail, but added in order to give point to her remonstrance at the removal of the stone, by emphasizing the natural reluctance of a sister to have the corrupted body of her brother exposed.

Not indicating an experience of her sense, which has been maintained by some expositors, and sometimes expressed in the pictorial treatment of the subject, but merely her inference from the fact that he had been dead four days.
John Calvin: Christ does not approach the sepulcher as an idle spectator, but as a champion who prepares for a contest.
He contemplated the transaction itself rather than the men.
Next follow various circumstances, which tend to display more fully the power of Christ in raising Lazarus.
Philip Schaff: The indignation was again excited either by the malicious comment just made by some of the Jews, or by the renewed recollection of the power of evil in the world.
Like Jewish tombs in general, this was a natural cave or, more probably, a vault artificially excavated in the limestone rock.
This verse again furnishes an indication that the family was not poor.
Archibald T. Robertson: The speculation concerning his power stirred the depths of his nature again.
Cometh to the tomb (ερχετα εις το μνημειον). Vivid historical present.

The use of a cave for burial was common (Genesis 23:19). Either the body was let down through a horizontal opening (hardly so here) or put in a tomb cut in the face of the rock (if so, επ can mean 'against').
John Gill: Jesus therefore groaning in himself... through an holy anger and indignation at the malice and wickedness of the Jews.
It would be better rendered here, and 'a stone was laid to it'; not 'upon it', for it had no opening above, but to it, at the side of it.
The covering for a grave, if it be made of a piece of timber, whether it stands, or whether it inclines to the side, does not defile, but over against the door only.
John Wesley: It was a cave — So Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and their wives, except Rachel, were buried in the cave of Machpelah."
These caves were commonly in rocks, which abounded in that country, either hollowed by nature or hewn by art.
And the entrance was shut up with a great stone, which sometimes had a monumental inscription.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, deeply moved once again, came to the tomb. It was a cave with a stone laid against it. This detail is not insignificant, as it emphasizes the reluctance of a sister to have the decaying body of her brother exposed. The use of a cave for burial was common during that time, and this burial cave, belonging to a family of wealth, had a stone placed over the entrance, mainly as a safeguard against wild animals. As Jesus approached the tomb, His groaning within Himself demonstrated both sorrow and righteous indignation, revealing the depth of His emotions as He prepared to confront death and display His power in raising Lazarus.

Jesus, deeply moved once again, approached the tomb, a cave with a stone laid against it. This cave burial was common, and the stone served to guard against wild animals. His groaning within Himself reflected his sorrow and righteous indignation, displaying the depth of His emotions as He prepared to confront death and demonstrate His power in raising Lazarus. This detail about the stone highlights the reluctance of a sister to expose her brother's decaying body, underscoring the family's wealth and Mary's objection.

Jesus, filled with emotion, approached the tomb of Lazarus, a cave that had a stone placed against it. This burial practice was common, signifying the family's wealth. The stone served as a protection against wild animals, but it also intensified Mary's objection to its removal, as she did not want her brother's corrupted body exposed. Jesus' groaning within Himself displayed both sorrow and righteous indignation, reflecting His deep emotions as He prepared to confront death and demonstrate His power in raising Lazarus.

Jesus, deeply moved once again, approached the tomb of Lazarus, and found a cave with a stone laid against it. The use of a cave for burial was common during that time, and this particular tomb, belonging to a wealthy family, had a stone placed over the entrance for protection. Jesus' groaning within Himself revealed a mixture of sorrow and righteous indignation as He prepared to confront death and demonstrate His power in raising Lazarus. This detail about the stone also highlighted Mary's objection to its removal, as it would expose the decaying body of her brother.

Filled with emotion, Jesus approached the tomb of Lazarus, a cave with a stone laid against it. The use of caves for burial was common, and this particular tomb belonged to a wealthy family. The stone served as protection against wild animals but also highlighted Mary's objection to its removal, as she did not want her brother's decaying body exposed. Jesus' groaning within Himself revealed a blend of sorrow and righteous indignation as He prepared to confront death and showcase His power in raising Lazarus.
